examples.en: Both Mr. and Mrs. Fugu live in Kagawa prefecture, but they live apart from each other now.
examples.ja: フグ夫妻は二人とも香川県には住んでいるが、別居中です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fragrance</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kagawa Prefecture</vocabulary>. Might help to look at the reading first.
reading_mnemonic:
This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help:

If you want to get to <vocabulary>Kagawa Prefecture</vocabulary> you're going to need a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!

examples.en: He likes conspiracies, but there is often a leap in his logic.
examples.ja: 彼は陰謀論が好きなんですが、彼の論理はよく飛躍するんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>fly</kanji> and <kanji>leap</kanji> is <vocabulary>leaping</vocabulary>.

飛躍 is mainly used in a figurative way to highlight remarkable progress in areas like personal growth or technological advancement. It can also describe a logic that jumps suddenly from one point to another without clear connections.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please say thank you to your mother.
examples.ja: お母様に宜しくお伝えくださいね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>best regards</kanji> and this can be <vocabulary>best regards</vocabulary> as well. It can also mean <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>properly</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>suitably</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.

readings: よろしくおねがいします

examples.en: Why do Japanese people say "please treat me well" all the time?
examples.ja: どうして日本人はいつも「宜しくお願いします」って言うの？

meaning_mnemonic: A 宜しい (good, okay, all right) <kanji>request</kanji> is when you send your <vocabulary>best regards</vocabulary> to someone. This is a set phrase you say when someone is going to help you out and you're all like "thank you for your help" or "I'm counting on you" or some combination of the two. It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 宜しい and お願いします.

examples.en: Can’t you stop repeating the same mistakes over and over?
examples.ja: 同じ失敗を何度も繰り返すのはやめようじゃないか。

meaning_mnemonic: 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this <vocabulary>to repeat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to repeat over and over</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.

examples.en: My senior and I found shelter under a cherry blossom tree when the rain started suddenly.
examples.ja: 雨が突然降り出したので、先輩と私は桜の木の下で避難しました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: <vocabulary>to evacuate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.

examples.en: People hung on Koichi’s every word.
examples.ja: みんな、コウイチの話に、一心に耳を傾けた。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lean</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to lean something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

examples.en: I’m sorry for the interruption, but it seems that your wife’s just gotten stuck in an elevator.
examples.ja: お話中恐れ入りますが、奥様がエレベーターに閉じ込められてしまったようなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>interior</kanji> <kanji>formal name ender</kanji> (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is <vocabulary>your wife</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Tomorrow is my physical check-up, so I’d rather not have alcohol today, if that’s okay.
examples.ja: 明日、健康診断なので、できれば今日はお酒はご遠慮させてください。

meaning_mnemonic: If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to decline</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to restrain</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.

examples.en: I’m worried if he is okay.
examples.ja: 彼の安否が気に懸かります。

meaning_mnemonic: If something is <kanji>suspend</kanji>ed, it is going <vocabulary>to hang</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary> your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!
reading_mnemonic: We're depending on you to help us to get this <reading>ca</reading>r (か), okay?

examples.en: I was moved by the sight of my daughter singing in the chorus with all her might.
examples.ja: 合唱団で歌う娘の一生懸命な姿に感動しました。

examples.en: Look, it's unfair that you're the only one slacking off, because everyone is working so hard.
examples.ja: ほら、みんな一生懸命がんばってるんだから、一人だけサボるなんてずるいよ。

examples.en: I know I have to work my hardest to catch up with everyone, but it’s difficult.
examples.ja: 遅れを取り戻すために一生懸命働かなくてはいけないのは分かっているんですが、中々難しいです。

meaning_mnemonic: You have only <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji> so do everything with lots of <kanji>eager</kanji>ness (懸命). Do everything <vocabulary>with all one's might</vocabulary>. Go <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary> to learn these readings!

examples.en: Right after I was told to be careful with the wine glass, sure enough, I broke one.
examples.ja: ワイングラスの扱いに気をつけるようにと言われた直後に、案の定一つ割ってしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is <vocabulary>handling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 扱う, so if you know that you'll have a good <vocabulary>handling</vocabulary> of this one.

examples.en: I’m going to handle that topic in the next article.
examples.ja: その話題については、次の記事で取り扱う予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>take</kanji> and then <kanji>handle</kanji> means you're taking it and handling it, causing you <vocabulary>to manage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to handle</vocabulary> something. You got it because you took it.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 扱う.

examples.en: Have you decided which girl to choose as your marriage partner?
examples.ja: 結婚相手にどちらの女性を選択するか決めましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going <vocabulary>to select</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to choose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.

examples.en: I was doing my Wanikani reviews every day and the teacher praised me for my diligence.
examples.ja: ワニカニのレビューを毎日していたら、先生から勤勉だと褒め称えられた。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>title</kanji>, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to give praise</vocabulary> to you.
reading_mnemonic: After they go <vocabulary>to praise</vocabulary> you, you're all like "I don't need praise! <reading>Ta-ta</reading> (たた)! I'm outa here."

examples.en: They are trying to whisper to each other, but their voices are so loud that I can hear everything.
examples.ja: 当人達は内緒話をしているつもりのようだが、声がでかいので全部筒抜けだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 内緒 means "secret" or "confidential"? Well, that makes this is a secret <kanji>talk</kanji>, aka a <vocabulary>confidential talk</vocabulary> — like the kind often done by <vocabulary>whispering</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi of 内緒 and kun'yomi of 話, only rendakued.

examples.en: Please feel free to loosen your necktie.
examples.ja: どうぞネクタイをお緩めになってください。

meaning_mnemonic: 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning <vocabulary>to loosen</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!

examples.en: This is a gift for my mother.
examples.ja: これは母への贈り物です。

examples.en: It seemed like a gift from God.
examples.ja: それはまるで、神様からの贈り物のようでした。

examples.en: The time spent choosing a gift is fun, isn't it?
examples.ja: 贈り物を選ぶ時間って楽しいよね。

examples.en: "Here's a present for you. It's dried fugu. I hope you like it." "Thanks. Just hearing what it is, I already really like it."
examples.ja: 「これ、君への贈り物。干しふぐだよ。気に入ってもらえるといいけど。」「有難う。聞いただけで既にとっても気に入ったわ。」

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 贈る, which means "to give a present"? Well, a <kanji>thing</kanji> that you give as a present is <vocabulary>a present</vocabulary>.

Since 贈り物 comes from the verb 贈る, it describes <vocabulary>a gift</vocabulary> not just as an object but as something given with care. You'll often see it in writing or polite speech when someone wants to emphasize the warmth or sincerity behind a gift.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 贈る and 物.

examples.en: We stopped everyone from leaving Okinawa Prefecture.
examples.ja: 我々は、人々が沖縄県から去るのを食い止めた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, <vocabulary>Okinawa Prefecture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

examples.en: This may be called a "present" in some countries, but in this country it's "bribery."
examples.ja: これは、ある国では「プレゼント」と呼ばれるかもしれないが、この国では「贈賄」である。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Presents</kanji> that you give as a <kanji>bribe</kanji> is a form of <vocabulary>bribery</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll never miss a chance to fall in love!
examples.ja: 恋愛のチャンスは逃さないよ！

examples.en: I missed the perfect shot when my husband sneezed.
examples.ja: 主人がクシャミをしたので、シャッターチャンスを逃してしまいました。

examples.en: I was out of it and missed the announcement.
examples.ja: ボーっとしていて、アナウンスを聞き逃してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means <vocabulary>to miss</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lose</vocabulary> a good chance, or <vocabulary>to let go</vocabulary> of a good opportunity.
reading_mnemonic:
Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word:

You <vocabulary>missed</vocabulary> a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was <reading>no ga</reading>s (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.

examples.en: I hear that the fugitive met a sick child while he was running away and decided to turn himself in.
examples.ja: 逃亡者は逃走中に病気の子どもに会い、自首を決意したそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who has <kanji>escape</kanji>d <kanji>death</kanji> by running away is a <vocabulary>fugitive</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>runaway</vocabulary>. I think there was a movie about that once!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why don't you ask your advisor if it's okay for you to miss club activities tomorrow?
examples.ja: 明日、部活を休んでもいいかどうか、顧問の先生に聞いてみたら？

examples.en: I didn't say I wanted to do it, but I was asked to be an advisor to that company.
examples.ja: 自分からやりたいと言ったわけではなくて、その会社の顧問をしてほしいと頼まれたんですよ。

examples.en: Rumor has it, he’s a good advisor for the basketball club.
examples.ja: 彼は良いバスケ部の顧問だとの評判があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The people who will <kanji>review</kanji> a <kanji>problem</kanji> are those who know more about the problems. They are the <vocabulary>advisor</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It's important to reflect on the past, but I think it's even more important to think about the future.
examples.ja: 過去を顧みることも大切だけど、未来のことを考える方がもっと大切だと思うんだ。

examples.en: When I look back on my childhood, I'm amazed at how I could do so many things without reflecting on the consequences.
examples.ja: 子どものころを顧みると、よくあんなに後先を顧みず色んなことをしたもんだと我ながら驚くよ。

examples.en: Honey, can’t you be a little more attentive to your own child?
examples.ja: あなた、我が子のことをもう少し顧みてあげてくれませんか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>review</kanji>. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning <vocabulary>to look back on something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to reflect on something</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>to be attentive to someone</vocabulary>, for example your family.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family.
reading_mnemonic: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.

examples.en: This is such a boring memoir.
examples.ja: なんてつまらない回顧録なんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>revolve</kanji> to <kanji>review</kanji> the <kanji>record</kanji> of the past. These records are <vocabulary>memoirs</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>reminiscences</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I have to go to a party tonight that is hosted by the U.S. Ambassador to Japan.
examples.ja: 今夜は駐日アメリカ大使主催のパーティーに行かなくちゃいけないんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something or someone <kanji>resident</kanji> in 日本 (Japan) is <vocabulary>stationed in Japan</vocabulary>.

駐日 is generally used to describe both individuals and institutions stationed in Japan for official duties, such as the 駐日大使 (Ambassador to Japan) or 駐日大使館 (embassy stationed in Japan).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A wife of an expatriate employee who came abroad with him is sometimes called Mrs. Expatriate.
examples.ja: 海外駐在員と一緒に外国に来ている妻は、駐在さんと呼ばれることがある。

meaning_mnemonic: You're a <kanji>resident</kanji> and you <kanji>exist</kanji> in the place you're residing in. That means you have <vocabulary>residence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m stuck in a traffic jam in a parking lot at the mall. I shouldn’t have come here on the Sunday before Christmas.
examples.ja: ショッピングモールの駐車場で渋滞に巻き込まれちゃってるよ。クリスマス前の日曜日なんかに、こんなところに来るんじゃなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>location</kanji> where <kanji>car</kanji>s can be a <kanji>resident</kanji> is a <vocabulary>parking lot</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

examples.en: Is there a laundry service for the stationed troops?
examples.ja: 駐留軍向けの洗濯サービスとかはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>resident</kanji> <kanji>detain</kanji>ed in a location who is in the <kanji>army</kanji> is a member of the <vocabulary>stationed troops</vocabulary> at this location. They could also be the <vocabulary>occupying troops</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We burst out laughing when we saw the teacher dashing down the hallway with his arms folded.
examples.ja: 先生が腕を組んだまま廊下を駆けて行くのを見て、大笑いしました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gallop</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gallop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: While shopping in the grocery store, I tether my dog to a pole and he always waits for me obediently.
examples.ja: そのスーパーで買い物をしてる間、私は犬を柱に繋ぐんですが、いつもちゃんと大人しく待ってますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: You'll have to imagine a <vocabulary>pillar</vocabulary> standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a <reading>hash-ra</reading> (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.

examples.en: I ran my car into a telephone pole today.
examples.ja: 今日車を電柱にぶつけちゃったんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>pillar</kanji> is a <vocabulary>telephone pole</vocabulary>. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When the tall wizard uttered the magic word, there was a moment of total darkness.
examples.ja: 背の高い魔法使いが呪文を唱えると、辺りは一瞬真っ暗になった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chant</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to chant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Really, when you are going <vocabulary>to chant</vocabulary>, the most important thing to do is to figure out your <reading>tone</reading> (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest  comes naturally.

examples.en: Could I meet the leading advocate of Bacon Peace?
examples.ja: ベーコンの平和を唱える主唱者にお会いすることはできますか？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>master</kanji> <kanji>chant</kanji>er is the one who is the loudest. He makes sure everyone hears his chants. He's the main <vocabulary>advocate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I don’t want to listen to the patriotic school song.
examples.ja: 愛国唱歌は聴きたくないね。

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>chant</kanji>ing and you're <kanji>sing</kanji>ing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're <vocabulary>singing</vocabulary> all your <vocabulary>songs</vocabulary> and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Even though I have hay fever, I have to do a solo in the recital.
examples.ja: 花粉症なのに、発表会で独唱しなくちゃいけないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>alone</kanji> <kanji>chant</kanji> is one you do alone. It's a <vocabulary>solo</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can I post this video on Facebook to show everyone your skills as a singer?
examples.ja: あなたの歌唱力をみんなに見せつけるために、このビデオをFacebookに投稿してもいいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>sing</kanji>ing and you're <kanji>chant</kanji>ing. It's a gay ol' time. You're <vocabulary>singing</vocabulary> and singing and singing!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The members of the choir are all singing hand in hand.
examples.ja: 合唱団員は、みんなで手を繋いで歌っています。

meaning_mnemonic: People who <kanji>join</kanji> in a <kanji>chant</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> are people who are in a <vocabulary>chorus</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>choir</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 合 is pretty weird. It's a がっ instead of a ごう. Just imagine a bunch of people in a chorus singing "ga ga ga ga gaaaa!"

examples.en: I want to do better by my parents, but I just don't have the time.
examples.ja: もっと親孝行したいけど、なかなか時間がないんだよね。

examples.en: She's known by all as a devoted daughter.
examples.ja: 彼女は孝行娘として有名です。

examples.en: My parents say "You can honor us just by staying happy and healthy," but that might actually be the toughest ask.
examples.ja: 親は「元気でいてくれるだけで孝行」と言うけど、それが実は一番難しいかもしれない。

examples.en: I wish I'd devoted myself more to my wife before she passed away.
examples.ja: 女房が死ぬ前に、もっと孝行しておくんだったな。

meaning_mnemonic: If you go towards filial piety, you are going to be doing filial piety. Do this for your parents. 孝行 is commonly used in the phrase 親孝行 (also meaning "filial piety") when someone does something kind or thoughtful for their parents, like visiting often, helping them, giving them a gift, or taking them on a trip. By extension, it can also sometimes describe showing devotion toward other loved ones — caring for and respecting them almost as though they were a parent.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I never want to do anything that would be disrespectful toward my family.
examples.ja: 自分の家族の不孝になるようなことは、絶対にしたくない。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Not</kanji> <kanji>filial piety</kanji> is when you don't listen to your parents. This is <vocabulary>disobedience to parents</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This textbook is designed for genius children, so it will be difficult for your kid.
examples.ja: この問題集は俊才児を対象にして作られているので、あなたのお子さんには難しすぎますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A person with <kanji>genius</kanji> and <kanji>talent</kanji> is a <vocabulary>genius</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>person of exceptional talent</vocabulary>. So smart!

俊才 is an advanced word usually only seen in writing. It tends to refer more to the kind of genius or talent that can be developed through effort. In that sense it differs from 天才, which is for the kind of genius that comes from heaven — either you have it or you don't.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>concurrently</kanji> <kanji>use</kanji> one thing for multiple purposes, you're using something with a <vocabulary>combined use</vocabulary>. Something that is <vocabulary>serving two purposes</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>concurrently</kanji>, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "<vocabulary>to combine</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to double as</vocabulary>." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
reading_mnemonic: For example, a <reading>ca</reading>r (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

examples.en: Why did it take you three hours to buy one bottle of detergent?

This is an <vocabulary>antiseptic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>preservative</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>ditch</kanji> is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the <vocabulary>outer moat</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>patrol</kanji>, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is <vocabulary>to go around</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of <reading>Meg</reading> (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

examples.en: The policeman drank half the scotch in one gulp.

Those who <kanji>patrol</kanji> and <kanji>inspect</kanji> are <vocabulary>police officer</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>patrol officer</vocabulary>s.

巡査 specifically refers to the lowest-ranking officers in the police force in Japan, whose duty is patrolling or doing things around 交番 (police boxes), or responding to emergency calls.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_mnemonic: My <kanji>instruction</kanji> is my <kanji>commandment</kanji>. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my <vocabulary>warning</vocabulary>. This is my <vocabulary>admonition</vocabulary>.

You never know what kind of carpentry or lumberjacking you'll be asked <vocabulary>to take part in</vocabulary>, and Taz saws are known for their versatility.

This word is formal and literary.

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>spread</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to lay out</vocabulary>.

This word generally refers to laying something flat, like a carpet or a picnic blanket. This use also extends to laying railroad tracks or asphalt for street paving. Metaphorically, it describes laying down something foundational, like establishing rules or specific organizational systems.
reading_mnemonic: What is getting <vocabulary>spread out</vocabulary>? <reading>Shee</reading>p (し)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.

examples.en: The use of "dono" after a name is used today only in written documents as an honorific title for those who are equal or inferior to you.
examples.ja: 名前の後に「殿」を付ける用法は、現代では同列か目下の人に対しての敬称として、書面にのみ用いられる。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>Milord</kanji>, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>, but nowadays it's closer to <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary>. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

Do you know a <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>? Imagine it being someone named <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary> <reading>Don</reading> (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

examples.en: I drew a handsome feudal lord to waste time.
examples.ja: 暇つぶしにイケメンの殿様の絵を描きました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Milord</kanji> (you say very formally with a <kanji>formal name ender</kanji>). You say it very formally because this person is a lord, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>feudal lord</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Feudal Lord</vocabulary>s were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My <reading>toe?! NO</reading>!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.

examples.en: The roof of the palace is supported by many pillars.

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Milord</kanji>'s <kanji>hall</kanji> is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A <vocabulary>palace</vocabulary>. By extension, this can also mean a <vocabulary>sanctuary</vocabulary>, and even a <vocabulary>hall of fame</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>transparent</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be transparent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be see-through</vocabulary>.

透ける is usually for things that are partially transparent or see-through because they're thin or sheer, like stockings and lace curtains. Sometimes people even joke that your true thoughts are 透けてる (showing through).
reading_mnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your dog, cat, plant, car, etc. is transparent that you <reading>sue</reading> the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If everything in life seems <vocabulary>empty</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>futile</vocabulary>, even cows will be affected. Listen to them say, "<reading>Moo, nah</reading> (むな), never mind. What's the point?" Nothing makes life seem empty like a cow saying "Moo, nah."

meaning_mnemonic:
You're so <kanji>glad</kanji>, you get <kanji>glad</kanji> again. No matter what you're doing, it's undoubtedly in a <vocabulary>state of enjoyment</vocabulary>.

嬉々 itself refers to a <vocabulary>joyful state</vocabulary> where someone happily does something. It's generally used as the adverb 嬉々として, which means “happily” or “gladly.” While less common, it can also serve as an adjective when combined with たる.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>glad</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: Whenever you're really <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary> to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "<reading>Ooh, ray</reading>s (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is <vocabulary>happy</vocabulary> you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

meaning_mnemonic:
In your <kanji>knee</kanji> there is a <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>priest</kanji> named <vocabulary>Kneecap</vocabulary>.

This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for 膝 and 小, but the on'yomi reading for 僧, which gets rendaku'd from そう to ぞう, so watch out for that! You've learned all these reading before, so you should be able to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic: You can guess this is an adjective by looking at the い it ends with. One of the meanings of the kanji, <kanji>enchanting</kanji>, is already an adjective. That's the meaning of this word, too: <vocabulary>enchanting</vocabulary>. What is enchanting? It's basically <vocabulary>charming</vocabulary> in a <vocabulary>mysterious</vocabulary> way.
reading_mnemonic:
So this <vocabulary>enchanting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>charming</vocabulary> feeling is <vocabulary>mysterious</vocabulary>... some would say 怪しい (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as 怪しい. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference:

怪しい usually has a negative feel to it whereas 妖しい generally has a positive feel. 妖しい also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.

examples.ja: 効果が薄まるので、お酒と一緒には飲まないで下さい。

examples.en: The pink paint, diluted with water, was left on the palette.
examples.ja: 水で薄まったピンクの絵の具がパレットに残っていた。

examples.en: With just one remark, the inherent value of the letter was diminished.
examples.ja: たった一つの発言でせっかくの手紙のありがたみが薄まった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>dilute</kanji>, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be diluted</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be diminished</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to become weak</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't want your drink <vocabulary>to be diluted</vocabulary>, so <reading>you sue</reading> (うす) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.

examples.en: Eat your noodles quickly or they'll get soft.
examples.ja: 早く食べないと麺が伸びちゃうよ。

examples.en: We've developed strawberry-flavored noodles.
examples.ja: 苺味の麺を開発しました。

examples.en: Next, pour boiling water over the noodles.
examples.ja: 次に、麺に沸騰したお湯を注いでください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some noodles to celebrate!

examples.en: Where did you buy that rolling pin?
examples.ja: その麺棒、どこで買ったの？

examples.en: If you're looking for a rolling pin, it's in that drawer.
examples.ja: 麺棒ならあそこの引き出しに入ってるよ。

examples.en: A large number of rolling pins have been brought in from China.
examples.ja: 大量の麺棒が中国から持ち込まれている。

meaning_mnemonic:
Grab your <kanji>noodle</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a <vocabulary>rolling pin</vocabulary>!

You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.

examples.en: I've been craving Chinese noodles all day.
examples.ja: 一日中、中華麺が食べたくて仕方がない。

examples.en: My mom's Chinese noodles are the best in the world.
examples.ja: 母の作る中華麺は世界で一番おいしい。

examples.en: We became rich exporting instant Chinese noodles to Europe.
examples.ja: インスタント中華麺をヨーロッパに輸出してお金持ちになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: You already know that 中華 means Chinese, and <kanji>麺</kanji> means noodles. Put them together and what have you got? That's right, <vocabulary>Chinese noodles</vocabulary>! Yum!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This mentsuyu is the best!
examples.ja: この麺つゆが最高においしいよ。

examples.en: With just three ingredients you can easily make homemade noodle soup base.
examples.ja: 三つの材料で簡単に手作り麺つゆができます。

examples.en: This noodle broth can be used in stews and other dishes.
examples.ja: この麺つゆは煮物などの料理にも使えます。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious <vocabulary>mentsuyu </vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>noodle soup base</vocabulary>. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar​. Yum!
reading_mnemonic: You learned the reading for 麺 when you learned the kanji.

examples.en: All the kidnapping victims have returned safely.
examples.ja: 拉致被害者全員が無事に帰ってきた。

examples.en: Why is there no progress on the abduction issue?
examples.ja: 拉致問題は、なぜ進まないのでしょうか。

examples.en: The traveler was taken captive by a gang of robbers but released a few days later.
examples.ja: その旅行者は強盗団に拉致されたが、数日後に放れた。

meaning_mnemonic: If someone <kanji>abduct</kanji>s what do they <kanji>do</kanji>? That's <vocabulary>abduction</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>kidnapping</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>taking captive</vocabulary>. This word comes up fairly frequently in Japanese newspapers, and is often used to refer to kidnappings carried out by North Korea in the seventies and eighties.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings: To Go Out Into The World
To Be Released To The Public

examples.en: It's a dream come true to have my work published.
examples.ja: 自分の作品が世に出るなんて、夢みたいだ。

examples.en: Once a photo or video goes out in the world, it becomes a digital tattoo and stays on the Internet forever.
examples.ja: 一度世に出た写真やビデオは、デジタルタトゥーとなってずっとネットに残るんだよ。

examples.en: In today's concert, I will perform pieces that have never before been released to the public.
examples.ja: 今日のコンサートでは、今まで世に出る機会がなかった曲たちを演奏します。

meaning_mnemonic: Here we have <kanji>world</kanji> with the particle に, following by the verb 出る (to go out). Put that together and this means <vocabulary>to go out into the world</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be published</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be released to the public</vocabulary> in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it <vocabulary>to become renowned</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!
